unnormalised: Bangalore, 16/07/2024 - In a move that has developers simultaneously cheering and facepalming, local software firm "Code Ninjas Pvt. Ltd." announced its latest "innovation": a coding platform that insists on naming all variables after Bollywood dance moves. Yes, you read that right. Forget "i," "j," or "count"—prepare to debug with "ChaiyyaChaiyya," "DhoomMachale," and the ever-popular "MunniBadnaam."
normalised: Bangalore, sixteenth July two thousand and twenty four - In a move that has developers simultaneously cheering and facepalming, local software firm "Code Ninjas Private Limited" announced its latest "innovation": a coding platform that insists on naming all variables after Bollywood dance moves. Yes, you read that right. Forget "i," "j," or "count"—prepare to debug with "ChaiyyaChaiyya," "DhoomMachale," and the ever-popular "MunniBadnaam."

unnormalised: According to CTO Mr. Rajesh Kumar, the platform aims to "spice up" the coding experience. "We were finding that our developers were falling asleep during code reviews," he explained, while demonstrably avoiding eye contact. "Now, at least, they're mumbling Bollywood lyrics under their breath instead! Productivity has increased by, uh, approximately 0.05%." Internal memos leaked to this reporter (sent via WhatsApp, naturally) suggest a slightly different story, with complaints about "syntax errors turning into impromptu dance-offs" and "debugging sessions resembling poorly choreographed wedding sangeets."
normalised: According to C-T-O Mister Rajesh Kumar, the platform aims to "spice up" the coding experience. "We were finding that our developers were falling asleep during code reviews," he explained, while demonstrably avoiding eye contact. "Now, at least, they're mumbling Bollywood lyrics under their breath instead! Productivity has increased by, uh, approximately zero point zero five percent." Internal memos leaked to this reporter (sent via WhatsApp, naturally) suggest a slightly different story, with complaints about "syntax errors turning into impromptu dance-offs" and "debugging sessions resembling poorly choreographed wedding sangeets."

unnormalised: The company boasts that the new platform supports Python, Java, and even good ol' C++, and that developers can now generate code "faster than you can say 'item number'." Industry experts are, shall we say, skeptical. "It's certainly…a choice," commented Ms. Priya Sharma, a senior developer at a rival firm. "I'm not sure if I'm more concerned about the increased debugging time or the sudden urge to break into a 'Sheila Ki Jawani' routine every time I encounter a null pointer exception."
normalised: The company boasts that the new platform supports Python, Java, and even good ol' C plus plus, and that developers can now generate code "faster than you can say 'item number'." Industry experts are, shall we say, skeptical. "It's certainly…a choice," commented Miss Priya Sharma, a senior developer at a rival firm. "I'm not sure if I'm more concerned about the increased debugging time or the sudden urge to break into a 'Sheila Ki Jawani' routine every time I encounter a null pointer exception."

unnormalised: Whether "BollywoodCode" will revolutionize the software development landscape or become a cautionary tale remains to be seen. In the meantime, aspiring developers are advised to brush up on their Bollywood trivia and maybe invest in some comfortable dancing shoes. Initial reports suggest support tickets related to "variable 'JaiHo' throwing unexpected exceptions" are already through the roof, making it "Quite the hungama," as one commenter puts it. One thing's for sure, Code Ninjas' annual Diwali party is going to be lit!
